numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I noticed that legacy applicants were admitted at a considerably higher rate than non-legacy applicants.
2. This difference happened irrespective of income.
3. The admission chance for students with the greatest income is a little more than two times the admission chance for students with the lowest income.
4. This difference is insignificant compared to the admission advantage of legacy applicants.
5. Some legacy applicants have a parent income rate of 99.9.
6. I wonder about the role of money in the admission process of the school.
7. I ask whether there is evidence of favoritism in the admission of legacy applicants.
8. I ask what distinguishes legacy applicants from non-legacy applicants.
9. I ask whether legacy applicants are superior applicants.
10. I ask whether the admission of legacy applicants depends on actions of alumni of the school.
11. This topic is relevant to me and to my community.
12. I am from an urban area.
13. Many of my peers are not legacy applicants.
14. Many of my classmates are not legacy applicants.
15. Many of my peers do not have parents who are alumni.
16. Many of my classmates do not have parents who are alumni.
17. Admission is more difficult for these peers and classmates.
18. Some of these peers and classmates are already at a disadvantage.
19. Some circumstances are beyond the control of these peers and classmates.
20. These circumstances cause the disadvantage.
21. The headline is: Rags To Riches, Is Favoritism Ending Fair Chances?
